Ahmad is a 28-year-old single man who has been in business selling DVDs and maintaining computers' spare parts since two years ago to cover his needs and expenses.

Ahmad is a hard worker and an ambitious man who has a good reputation in his region. Today, he is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to develop his business through buying necessary computer maintenance tools and stock of DVDs.

Ahmad hopes to expand his business more in the future to increase his income and improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to develop his business through buying stock of DVDs and computer maintenance tools.

loans.name: Omary

texts.en:
The borrower, who is in his early 30s, is married with four children who are still in school. He has been selling chips and paraffin since 1989. He works from 08am to 11pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be the borrower's 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to increase his stock of chips and tins of paraffin, and has paid back his loan successfully. He used the profit to pay school fees, loan repayment and covered household expenses. He will use this loan to buy Irish potatoes, cooking oil, charcoal for cooking, and paraffin oil to resell. He dreams of building a house for renting.

He will make sure to pay back his loan successfully.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes, cooking oil, charcoal for cooking, and paraffin oil to resell.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou, 49, is a married woman with five children. Three of them attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Marilou has a rice retailing business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more rice to sell. Marilou has been in this business for seven years. 

In the future, Marilou would like to save money, expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more rice to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Lyn

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Ma. Lyn works hard to support her family. She has a business selling spices in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store. 

Ma. Lyn is borrowing 29,500 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stock of spices to sell in her stall. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 26 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of spices to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
As a married mother of seven children, Rogelia works hard to support her family.

She has a fish-vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Rogelia is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to buy more seafood to sell for her fish-vending business.

Rogelia has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more seafood to sell.

loans.name: Generosa

texts.en:
Generosa is 62 years old and married with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Generosa has a food production business in the Philippines. Generosa requested a PHP 26,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Generosa has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Generosa would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Karima

texts.ru: Карима, 54 года, замужем, мать 5 детей (2 сына и 3 дочери). Образование- средне-специальное, с 2000 года занимается животноводством. Благодаря упорному труду и терпеливому характеру Каримы, на сегодняшний день она имеет хорошее хозяйство: 6 коров, 4 лошади и 16 овец. Ежемесячная прибыль Каримы составляет до 20,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Карима обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота. Доходы от кредита Карима планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья, что позволит ей улучшить благосостояние семьи.
texts.en: Karima is 54, married, and the mother of five children (two sons and three daughters). She has a vocational education and has been raising livestock since 2000. Thanks to her hard work and patient nature she currently has six cows, four horses and 16 sheep. She earns up to 20,000 som (KGS) per month. In order to expand her business, Karima applied for a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) with Bai Tushum Bank to purchase livestock. She plans to use the earnings from the loan to invest in additional livestock, which will enable her to improve her family’s well-being.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock in order to increase her herd

loans.name: Dimphina's Group

texts.en:
Dimphina, pictured above, has been a farmer for more than 40 years. She is proud to represent her group of 11 farmers in Matete district, Kenya. She is 62 years old, married and has eight children.

Dimphina likes to think of herself as a very hardworking individual. She has been working alongside One Acre Fund since 2012 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to gain leadership skills. She says that being part of the One Acre Fund community has meant that she has had more profits from each harvest. Dimphina plans to use the profits from this coming season to send her children to school.

In total, Dimphina’s group will receive inputs to cultivate 7.25 acres of land and four solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvests of maize.

loans.name: Armine

texts.en:
Armine, her brother and mother live in Mrgastan village of Ejmiatsin region. All three are occupied in land cultivation work. Near the house where Armine and her family live, they own arable land and cultivate haricot, potatoes, cabbage, and greens and sell the gathered harvest.

The earned income is hardly enough for covering daily living costs, so nothing remains to invest in the farm. That's the reason why Armine has applied for this loan. She asks lenders to support her to purchase potato seeds, fertilizer, and oxen.

This is her second loan. Armine faced difficulties in paying her first loan to another financial institution because of hard financial times for the family. Now, ensuring that their farming business is sustainable enough to cover monthly loan payments, Armine has applied for this loan.

She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Through this program, more than 600 loans were disbursed, 80% of which were funded and helped individuals like Armine to develop their businesses.

loans.use: to pay for potato seeds, fertilizer, and oxen to enlarge the farming business and gather income for the family's living.

loans.name: Carminia

texts.es: Hace 20 años, Carminia inició su expereincia en el arte de la confección, trabajando en diversos talleres que le proporcionaron el aprendizaje para que tiempo despues decidiera emprender su propio negocio, pues se cansó de ser empleada y se dedicó a manejar su tiempo con sus propios requerimeintos ofreciendo servicios de confección a lamedida, trabajando a todo costo y tambien maquilando a otras empresas que le solicitan sus servicios de ensamblado de ropa. Sus venatas las realiza de contado diariamente trabaja en su taller desde las 7 de la mañana ahsta las 7 de la noche sin descanso, comprando de contado y a crédito, telas e insumos que requiera a la medida de lo que marque el mercado. Ella tambien arregla prendas de vestir en la comunidad y con ello recibe ingresos adicionales. Sus principales clientes son sus vecinos y fábricas vecinas, que conocen la calidad con la cual trabaja y hacen aprecio a su dedicación a este oficio. En la actualidad Carminia está apalicano a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la aFundación Mario Santo Domingo,  mediante el cual comprará telas, hilos, botones, correderas o cierres etc. Con esta inversión incrmentará su productivididas, la exhibición de sus inventarios será mayor, repercutiendo en sus ventas, haciendo de su credikiva una inversión exitosa.
texts.en:
Carminia's experience in dressmaking began 20 years ago. After some time working in various workshops, which gave her the opportunity to learn, she decided to start her own business as she became tired of being an employee.  She worked to her own schedule and requirements, offering made to measure dressmaking services, for all budgets and other businesses that request her clothes making services. 

Her daily sales are carried out in cash and she works in her workshop from 7 in the morning until 7 at night without resting.  She buys, in cash and credit, the fabrics and materials according the requirements of the market. She also repairs clothes in the community and gets extra income from this. 

Her main clients are her neighbours and local manufacturers who know the quality of her work and appreciate her dedication to the profession.

Carminia is currently applying for a credikiva, the first loan that she has applied for from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with which she will buy fabrics, thread, buttons, zips etc.  With this investment she will increase her productivity and her stock levels will be higher. This will have and effect on sales and make her credikiva loan successful.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, thread, buttons, zips etc.

loans.name: Lilian's Group

texts.en:
Lilian's Group is formed by 14 farmers in Matete District and is being represented by Lilian, who is the group leader pictured above. She is 34 years old, is married and has 3 children. Lilian has been a farmer for 15 years and is often referred to as a very reliable person.

Lilian isn’t new to One Acre Fund, she actually joined the program in 2013 and has since noticed her life has changed; especially in the sense that she has been able to consistently feed her family ever since. This year, Lilian will not only get fertilizer and maize seeds as part of her loan, but will also purchase a solar light. She is very excited about this addition since now she will be able to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study.

Using this loan, Lilian's Group will purchase a total of 15 solar lights and use the farming inputs received to plant a total of 7 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light, as well as hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvests of maize.

loans.name: Mable's Group

texts.en:
Mable, pictured above, has been a farmer for more than 30 years, and is now proud to represent her group of 8 farmers in Matete District. She is 58 years old, is married and has 6 children.

Mable likes to think of herself as a very hardworking individual. She has been working alongside One Acre Fund since 2013 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. She says that being part of the One Acre Fund community has meant that she has been able to save more money. Mable plans to use the profits from this coming season to save more money for the future.

In total, Mable’s Group will receive inputs to cultivate 6 acres of land. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan, the group will also receive a total of 5 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvests of maize

loans.name: Nurije

texts.en:
Nurije and her husband are Egyptian Albanians who previously asked for your financial help to make some emergency repairs to their home. When I, the writer, visited them for an impact interview I became aware of their real situation:

One of their daughters who was a divorcee and a mother of two daughters was diagnosed with a fatal illness and later passed away leaving the two daughters in the care of her parents who lived in a balcony of an apartment building, on the first floor. The balcony was their house, no toilet, no kitchen and eventually no running water. These two grand daughters got married and both got divorced with 3 and 2 kids respectively, and came back to the grandparents with their children. Seven people now slept on the floor on some cardboard and old blankets and clothes. All of the great grandchildren suffered from some disease and required immediate health specialist visitations. Thus, Nurije spent the loan they had received from you on their great grandkids' health instead. We learned that about five months ago the granddaughters with their children received some help from churches in Greece where they have been living since.

Nurije now wants your financial help to make those little renovations and additions to their home that they intended previously. They seek your compassion and understanding!!!

loans.use: to make repairs to their house; they live extremely poorly.

loans.name: Nassoun's Group

texts.fr: Nassoun qui se trouve sur la photo au deuxième rang à droite, et qui est debout et porte un foulard noir , est membre d’un groupe de 11 agriculteurs inscrits à myAgro, vivent et travaillent dans le village de Ticko au sud-ouest de Bamako au Mali. Nassoun, âgée de 46 ans, est la mère de 12 enfants âgés de 15 à 34ans, dont 12 d’entre eux sont actuellement scolarisés. L’ancrage de la tradition familiale dans la pratique agricole, source principale de revenu et de l’autosuffisance alimentaire du foyer, mais aussi son mariage avec un agriculteur, ont incité Nassoun à exercer cette activité depuis maintenant 40ans. Nassoun cultive l'arachide sur sa parcelle mais doit faire face en tant qu’agricultrice à des difficultés telles que le manque de pluie et de matériels agricoles. Nassoun entame sa première année avec myAgro, et s'est inscrite en raison du système de paiement  et de la perspective de pouvoir augmenter son rendement à travers les services proposés par myAgro. Cette année Nassoun effectue des paiements pour acheter un paquet myAgro des semences OPV et d'engrais pour la culture d'arachide afin d’augmenter ses rendements sur sa parcelle de 0,0625 hectare. Cela fait maintenant 40ans que Nassoun cultive l'arachide pour sa valeur vivrière, expliquant que l’arachide est directement consommable par la famille et est utilisée comme sauce de base dans l’alimentation et aussi pour sa rentabilité productive et marchande. Nassoun planifie avec l’augmentation de ses rendements et de son revenu  de faire de l'élevage et acheter du matériel agricole. Enfin Nassoun espère aussi pouvoir construire une maison pour la famille ainsi que autosuffisance alimentaire.
texts.en:
Nassoun is standing in the back row on the right and wearing a black scarf. She is a member of a group of 11 farmers signed up with myAgro. They live and work in the village of Ticko, southwest of Bamako in Mali. 

Nassoun, 46 years old, is the mother of 12 children ages 15 to 34; all 12 have received formal schooling. Nassoun started farming over 40 years ago as a result of her family's long-standing tradition of agriculture as the main source of revenue and food self-sufficiency for the household, and her marriage to a farmer.  

Nassoun grows groundnuts on her land, but she face challenges such as the scarcity of rain and lack of farming equipment. This is her first year with myAgro; she signed up because of the payment system and the potential to bolster her productivity through the services available. This year, Nassoun is making payments to purchase a myAgro packet of OPV seeds and some fertilizers to grow groundnuts and increase the yield on her .0625-hectare holding. It has now been more than 40 years since Nassoun started growing groundnuts for its value as a staple food, explaining that it is directly edible by the family, and it is used as a base sauce in cooking; it is also a profitable crop. 

With increased yields and revenue, Nassoun plans to buy farming equipment and to start breeding animals. 

Nassoun hopes to be able to build a house for her family and to achieve self-sufficiency with respect to food.

loans.use: to purchase a packet of OPV seeds and some fertilizers to grow groundnuts.

loans.name: Tatsogola Group

texts.en:
Fidesi is 45 years, married with eight children. She used to be a farmer and loans helped her start her new business. She sells fish by the side of the road and depends on her business for her family's daily needs. 

Fidesi started this business to be economically empowered and independent. 

She will use the loan to expand her business by purchasing more fish, as this will help her to increase her profits. Fidesi plans to hire someone to help her run her business and hopes to improve her families living standards.

The loans have helped her become independent and enable her to pay school fees for some of her children.

loans.use: to buy fish.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Caroline. She is 43 years old, and married with six children.

Caroline joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) to benefit from training especially on enterprise development and financial management. Caroline practices farming. She is borrowing a loan to purchase a sprinkler and hosepipe for irrigation on her farm, which she needs especially during the dry season. She will be able to increase her production and earn more income to pay for her children's school fees.

Caroline is grateful to Kiva and her lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to purchase a sprinkler and hosepipe for irrigation on her farm during the dry season.

loans.name: Holien/bee Gichobo Project Group

texts.en:
The person raising his hand in the photo is Moni. He is a member of Holien/bee Gichobo Project. Moni is 57 years old, and married with four children. All of his children are in primary school. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2012.

Moni farms maize, and also operates a bodaboda business. He is happy for the entrepreneurship training he received from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa, which has helped him gain the business knowledge and skills to operate his business. 

Moni is borrowing a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers. The loan will raise his income, which will enable him to cater to his family's needs more effectively and pay school fees for his children. Moni is happy with Kiva and its lenders, and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer to improve farm outputs.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Justina, forty-nine years old, married and blessed with thirteen children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014.

She does crop farming, growing maize and potatoes. She gained knowledge through Hand in Hand training on enterprise start up and development.

She is borrowing a loan to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and seeds. This will increase her yields; hence she will be in a position to provide food to her children and continue supporting her family’s needs, thus improving their standard of living.

Justina is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds to improve crop yield.

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Ashura, who is in her early 40s, is married and has two children who are still at school. She has been selling fish for 20 years now. She works from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Ashura's 10th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to keep increasing her fish stock and has paid back all her loans successfully. She is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for their support. She used the profit to pay school fees, make loan repayments, buy a plot of land, build her own house, cover household expenses, and buy a TV set, a radio, beds, and cupboards.

Ashura will use this loan to buy fish and meet her customers' demand. She dreams of becoming an international business woman.

Ashura will hold herself responsible for making sure her loan gets paid back successfully.

loans.use: to buy fish and meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Al Wafaa 7 Group

texts.en:
Ayda is a 46-year-old married woman who has been working as a Tupperware saleswoman since three years ago to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family.

Ayda is a hard worker who is trying hard to develop her business. Thus, today she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise with a new collection of Tupperware. Ayda is the first lady on the left in the photo.

With respect to the other group members, Layal is a 28-year-old married mother of one child who wants to prepare for her childbirth, while Wafaa is a 60-year-old married mother of one child who wants to help her son in paying his wedding expenses.

Layal is the first lady on the right, and Wafaa is the lady sitting in the middle.

loans.use: to increase her merchandise with a new collection of Tupperware.

loans.name: Lina Luz

texts.en:
Lina Luz is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with one child.

She has an Internet café in the Philippines and requested a PHP 23000 loan through NWTF to buy additional "unit" for her café.

Lina Luz also industriously earns additional income through other business ventures including a general store and tailoring.

Lina Luz dreams that one day she will be able to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional "unit" for her internet café.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is 45 years old and married with one child. Susana works very hard to provide for them.

Susana runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Susana has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, noodles, and other groceries.

In the future, Susana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Abu- Bakarr

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Abu Bakarr. He is married and has four children, aged 2, 6, 8 and 12. In 2005, Abu Bakarr established his electronic and flashing light items business. He began his business just to improve his standard of living. Working six days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about SLL 1,972,500 every month from this business.

He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Abu Bakarr has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase more cartons of lamp chains and other electronic items for resale. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits and to increase his capital greatly.

In the future, Abu Bakarr still plans to expand his business, to educate his children and to build another house. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy additional  electronics items for his shop for resale.

loans.name: Vanis

texts.en:
Hello! Meet Vanis, 26 years of age, a very hardworking, honest, and dedicated farmer who lives in Ekerenyo, a remote village in Nyamira. 

She is happily married and is blessed with one adorable child. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last three years and has gained so much experience. 

To afford a decent and comfortable life for her child, Vanis also sells milk, eggs and varieties of food crops from her farmland. To make ends meet and earn extra cash, she has engaged in another small personal business: riding poultry. The Nyamira area is very populated and demand for poultry products and eggs is very high. 

Like many farmers from her region, she finds poultry farming very enjoyable and profitable. Her biggest challenge, however, is meeting the demand, which is really high. She lacks funds to increase her poultry farming, and she is seeking a loan of 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) to buy poultry. 

Being a woman, accessing funds is very challenging, but through institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva, she feels relieved knowing that her dream will be achieved and that she will be able to buy more poultry. 

Through this loan, Vanis will sell eggs and poultry products to her neighbors and at the local market. This will translate to increased profits and an improved income level. 

Being a visionary woman, Vanis intends to accumulate more profits and increase her poultry market to other markets, and this will increase her income and improve her living conditions. Her extra income will repay the loan and permanently changing her living conditions and secure a brighter future for her school-going child.

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: Dianna

texts.en:
This is Dianna's second loan from Kiva. She used her first loan to cover her daughter Anjela's university tuition. Now, after successfully paying the first one back, Dianna asks lenders for the support again. She needs the loan for paying her daughter's tuition fee.

Dianna's whole family will be very grateful to lenders to receive their support one more time.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter Anjela's university tuition

loans.name: Beatrice's Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is 42 years old and has six children. She is a group leader and is represents 10 farmers in Matete district, Kenya. 

Beatrice has been farming with One Acre Fund since 2011. Her decision was largely a result of her desire to earn enough money to send her children to school. And, although she described her last harvest as good, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. 

Beatrice also decided to purchase a solar light as part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to have light during dark hours for her children to study.

Obtaining this loan means that Beatrice's group will be able to receive a total of five solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 6.75 acres.

loans.use: to purchase solar lights, hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Petrit

texts.en:
This is Petrit, or "Sparrow Hawk’" in English, standing in front of his one-room family house.  He is 56 years old and a father of four, ranging in age from nine to 24. 

Petrit has applied for this loan to buy a dairy cow; currently he’s got one.

The activities that he and his wife have pursued for some years now are agriculture, livestock and transportation. 

Annually, they sells about five liters of raw milk daily, for about nine months, and one baby calf. They produce fresh veggies, grains and fruits such as persimmons, cherries and plums as well, but do not sell them. 

Petrit's wife actually does the agriculture/livestock and he transports people with the minivan.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La joven tiene 26 años de edad y es casada. Padece miopía severa con mas de nueve dioptrías por lo que   esta expuesta a sufrir un desprendimiento de retina debido a la alta de graduación.
Por su miopía severa  es urgente realizarle una cirugía  por que de no hacerlo pudiera llegar a perder la vista de manera irreversible, ya que desde hace años esta sin ningún tratamiento.
texts.en:
This young woman is 26 years old, and she is married.  She suffers from severe myopia with over nine diopters [unit of measure of the refractive power of a lens].  Therefore, she is likely to suffer a retinal detachment due to the degree of correction needed.

Because of her severe myopia, it is urgent to have surgery. By not doing so, she could lose her vision permanently.  She has not had any treatment for years.

loans.use: to pay for opthalmic treatment.

loans.name: Ndokanio Ya Munyuni Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Regina, a member of Ndokanio ya munyuni women group. She is 44 years old, married and a mother of six children, three of whom are attending school. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2013 to be trained on enterprise development skills.

Regina operates a clothes-selling business. She is borrowing to buy more new clothes for resale, to add stock and meet her customers' needs.

She appreciates Kiva and her lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes for resale, to add stock and meet her customers' needs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds that will help boost farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for dental treatment.

loans.name: Saffiatu

texts.en: This is 39-year-old Saffiatu. She is married, and has two children who are 11 and 14 years old -- both are still in school. She has one additional dependent fostered child who lives with her. In 2007, Saffiatu established her provisions and drinks business. She began her business because she wanted to help with some domestic problems at home. Working 6 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about Le 4,401,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. She has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase cartons of assorted provisions like sardines, powder milk, tin milk, sugar, ovaltines, etc. for resale. In the future, Saffiatu plans to reinvest and develop her business and educate her children.  Her previous loan helped her greatly and she was able to pay her suppliers on time. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase cartons of assorted provisions.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanajuma is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be positive. She operates a restaurant. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of ingredients to prepare food. She will use the anticipated profits to open another restaurant.

loans.use: buy more stock of ingredients to prepare food.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene is a married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself to be jovial and dedicated. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, flour, bananas, sweets, soap and other items. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located in a busy place and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more sugar, flour, sweets, soap and other items to sell. Her business goal is to open another business outlet within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will own a supermarket. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, flour, sweets, soap and other items

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is a hardworking married man with two children aged three and one. They live in Kamwenge, Uganda. He has a retail shop and also grows crops to earn additional income. 

Wilson hopes to expand his business and trade wholesale. However, his main challenge is the increased number of defaulters and that limits his expected profits. 

Wilson is requesting for a loan to buy bread, rice, salt, soap and sugar to sell.

loans.use: to buy bread, rice, salt, soap and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Nasira

texts.ru: Насира, 50 лет, замужем, мать 3 детей. На протяжении 21 года занимается животноводством и полеводством, мастер в своем деле. У Насиры среднее образование. По хозяйству активно помогают дети. Она достигла больших успехов в своем бизнесе. В хозяйстве имеет 2 коровы, 20 овец, лошадь. Также есть земельный надел, 3,09 ГА собственной земли, где она выращивает фасоль для реализации. Совокупная прибыль Насиры составляет около 15,000 сом (KGS). Она является лидером группы "Келечек Озгоруш", в которой кроме нее состоят еще 2 человека, всего их 3. Насира обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 35,000 сом (KGS) на покупку удобрений, семян фасоли, что позволит ей развить бизнес и увеличить доходы.
texts.en:
Nasira is 50 and married with three children. She has been working in animal husbandry and agriculture for 21 years and is skilled in her field. She has a high school education. Her children help her with the farm and she has achieved great success in her business. She has two cows, 20 sheep and a horse on her farm as well as 3.09 hectares of land where she grows beans for sale. Her total income is about 15,000 KGS. She is the leader of the Kelechek Ozgorush group, which consists of two people besides herself.

Nasira has approached Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 35,000 KGS to purchase fertilizer and bean seeds, which will allow her to develop her business and increase her income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, fuel and seeds in order to grow organic beans

loans.name: Dinah's Group

texts.en:
Dinah is 45 years old and described herself to others as a very hardworking individual. She has two children and is married. 

As a group leader, Dinah is representing 12 farmers in Matete district in Kenya who are very excited to be working with One Acre Fund for their first time this year.

The decision to join One Acre Fund was largely a result of Dinah's desire to earn enough money to send her children to school. 

Apart from receiving farming inputs, Dinah is also purchasing a solar light as part of her loan, which is very exciting to her and improve her overall quality of life. With the profits, Dinah will gain from this year’s harvest, she plans to send her children to school.

Dinah and her group will receive a total of eight solar lights as well as farm input to plant a total of 6.75 acres."

loans.use: to buy hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Selpher's Group

texts.en:
Pictured above is Selpher, often described as an extremely resourceful person. She is 32 years old, and as the group leader she is representing her group of 16 farmers in Matete District, Kenya. She is married and has three children.

Selpher is returning this season to work with One Acre Fund again as this means that she is able to get the best quality fertilizer and hybrid seeds, which is why she decided to join in the first place. Selpher says that she is happy to have made that decision because, since she first joined in 2013, she has gained a lot of respect in her community, which has improved her day-to-day life significantly. Selpher will use the profits from this season to buy a cow.

The group will use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of 8.25 acres. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan the group will also receive a total of eight solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher of Kamwenge, Uganda has three children aged nine, six and four. They attend primary school. 

He has a coffee plantation and operates a retail shop to earn income. Christopher plans to expand his business and pay school fees for his children. 

The big challenge he faces is pests and diseases that attack his coffee, causing him losses. 

Christopher will use the loan to hire labor to weed his coffee and sugarcane plantation.

loans.use: to hire labor to weed his coffee and sugarcane plantation.

loans.name: Bunena Tukwatanise 'a' Group

texts.en:
Longino is a 56 year old hardworking married man living in Kamwenge, Uganda. He has seven children and earns a living from his coffee plantation. 

He also does extra work as a church Catechist. He has a vision of expanding his coffee plantation to support his family. He however has a challenge of price fluctuation of agricultural produce. 

Longino is requesting a loan to buy manure, mulche and pesticides for his garden.

loans.use: to buy manure, mulche and pesticides for his garden.

loans.name: Ngiini Grace S.h.g Group

texts.en:
Mary, 42, is the the lady raising her hand in the photograph. She is a member of Ngiini Grace S.H.G group. She is married and a mother of three children. 

Mary owns a general retail shop and sells household stuff, like cereal, sugar, cooking fat,wheat flour, salt and more. She wants to increase her inventory and profits.

Mary is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the financial support, and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to increase her store's inventory of items to sell.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Stephen, a resilient farmer from Lemotit in South Rift, Kenya, who has defied the common thinking of the local farmer as reflected in his business. Stephen is a proud owner of a small tomato farming business that produces the vegetable throughout the year at affordable prices.
 
Doing tomato farming has a lot challenges, which Stephen simply overcomes by employing youthful energy, enthusiasm and the knowledge he has gathered with experience. He has big plans ahead to expand the business and he is already taking the first step: applying for a loan to grow more tomatoes.
 
Your loan will mean a lot to Stephen, since it will enable him to pay for inputs, tools and the labor that it takes to grow additional tomato crops. His family will greatly benefit from increased output and income. In the long run, the family's living conditions will be improved.

loans.use: to grow more tomatoes

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 39 years old, married to Hyrine, and blessed with six children. He has been practising tree farming for the last six years and earns 16,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month.

George has applied for his first loan of 25,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow so as to supply milk for his clients for more income. He plans to use the anticipated profits to expand his projects. His future hope and dream is to have well-educated children and large business activities.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow so as to supply milk for his clients for more income.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a married woman with one child. She describes herself as, positive. 

She operates a retail business where she sells vegetables. Zainab has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. 

She says her biggest business challenge is insufficient capital. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more vegetables. 

Her business goal is to be a supplier within five years. Zainab will use her anticipated profits to open a new business.

loans.use: buy more stock of vegetables.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase farm inputs to improve her farm's productivity.

loans.name: Stefany Paola

texts.es:
Stefany Paola es una joven estudiante de medicina, ella solicita un préstamo para poder continuar sus estudios de medicina, esta es su historia: 
Mi nombre es Stefany, tengo 23 años de edad y soy estudiante de Medicina en la Universidad UTESA en Santiago, Republica Dominicana. 
Hablando un poco sobre la historia de mi vida, nací n Santiago el 25 de agosto del 1991 y vengo de una familia que estaba integrada por 6 personas, mis padres, mis hermanos y por supuesto yo. Mi padre murió a los 52 años cuando yo tenía 11 años y luego mi hermano murió  a sus 16 años. 
Termine mis estudios de bachiller a los 16 años de edad en el Liceo Nocturno José Francisco Peña Gomez, pero no pude iniciar mis estudios universitarios desde que me gradué debido a problemas económicos. Dos años más tarde pude iniciarlos debido a que una de mis hermanas me ayudaba con el pago. Actualmente estoy solo a 5 materias para empezar el internando en Medicina. 
Siempre soñé con ser doctora desde que era pequeña, pues me gustaría poder ayudar a que las personas tengan una mejor calidad de vida y no me vería estudiando otra carrera, por lo que sería de gran ayuda poder lograr el préstamo de Kiva, y así lograr mi meta de ser una gran doctora.
texts.en:
Stefany Paola is a young medical student who is asking for a loan so she can continue her education.  This is her story:

My name is Stefany and I’m 23 years old and am a medical student at Universidad UTESA in Santiago, Dominican Republic.

To tell you a little about my life’s history, I was born in Santiago on August 25, 1991 and I come from a family that was made up of six persons, my parents, my siblings, and me of course.  My father died at age 52 when I was 11 years old and then my brother died at age 16.

I finished by bachelor’s studies at José Francisco Peña Gomez, night school, but I was not able to begin my university education immediately following my graduation due to financial problems.  I was able to begin two years later because my sister was able to help me with the cost.  Now I’m only five classes from starting my medical internship.

I have dreamed of becoming a doctor since I was a little girl because I like to help people to have better qualities of life and I would not have liked a different career.  This Kiva loan will be of great help in reaching my goal of becoming a great doctor.

loans.use: to pay medical school tuition.

loans.name: Anwar

texts.en:
Anwar, 23, is a married woman with one child. She is a very hardworking family provider. She completed education but she did not find suitable work; therefore she started to educate students in her home with private classes.

Anwar very ambitious, young woman who wants to provide the best for her family. She wanted to do more for her family and decided to open a general store to increase her income. 

Now Anwar requests a loan to purchase new products to sell to expand her work. 

She would like to save money to build a new home and provide good educate for her children.

loans.use: to purchase new products to sell and expand her work.

loans.name: Makena Single Mothers Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Ann, seventy-one years old and a widow with six children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014.

She does farming of maize and beans. She gained knowledge through Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training on enterprise start up and development. She is borrowing a loan to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers in order to increase her produce, thus meeting the demand for maize and beans in the area. This will improve her income, hence putting her in a position to pay school fees for her two grandchildren and continue supporting her family needs, thus improving their standard of living.

Ann is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs that will improve crop yield, thus adding more income to cater for the family needs.

loans.name: Jorge Humberto

texts.es:
Jorge se desempeña exitosamente en su negocio de cerrajería y soldadura de metal, siendo una persona muy reconocida en el barrio por su buen trabajo y servicio. 

Ya que ha laborado 15 años con los conocimientos que adquirió por medio de su trabajo en distintos talleres años atrás, ha tenido la oportunidad de mantener su trabajo y ha intentado mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia. 

Trabaja todos los días durante 7 horas solo.

Por esta razón quiere solicitar un crédito para la compra de hierro, soldadura y pintura. 
Con estos elementos podrá continuar prestando su servicio ya que le hace falta capital de trabajo.

Actualmente es casado y tiene dos hijos. 

Su mayor sueño es poder tener un gran taller con varios empleados y poco a poco podrá lograr su objetivo. 

Ayuda a un hombre emprendedor con ganas de salir adelante con un préstamo!
texts.en:
Jorge successfully works in his business of locksmithing and welding of metals. He is a well known person in the neighborhood for his good work and services.  

Since he has worked 15 years with the knowledge he acquired through work in various workshops, he has been able to perform his work and has tried to improve the living conditions of his family. He works everyday for 7 hours only. 

He is asking for a loan to purchase metal, welding supplies, and paint. With these items he can continue to perform his services, as he needs to have the working capital.

Currently he is married and he has two children. His biggest dream is to have a large workshop with several employees and gradually he will try to achieve this goal.

Help an enterprising man with a desire to succeed with a loan!

loans.use: to purchase metal, welding supplies, and paint.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To cover her university fees and achieve her dreams

loans.name: Sarai

texts.en:
Sarai is 19 years old. She operates a business of selling banana and taro in her community to earn a living. She has been doing this for more than a year. Sarai has requested a loan to buy banana tube seedlings, taro root seedlings, a wheelbarrow, a water tank, hand gloves, a rake, a shovel, and chemicals to assist her run the business. 

She joined SPBD in 2015, and hopes to use her business profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy banana tube seedlings, taro root seedlings, a wheelbarrow, a water tank, hand gloves, a rake, a shovel, and chemicals

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 25-years-old married man from Gaza City. 

He has a store for selling sanitary products which has been opened for the past seven years.  It is a good business and the only one in his area.

Ahmad took a loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy more inventory for his sanitary store to resell.  This will increase his sales and also his income.

Ahmad appears in the photo

loans.use: to buy more inventory for his sanitary store to resell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a married woman. She has 6 children. She describes herself as competent. 

She operates a farm where she grows maize and also keeps cows. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a productive area.  She describes her biggest business challenge to be bad weather. 

She will use the 100,000 KES loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pay for preparation costs. 

She hopes that in the future she will have a stable income. 

This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to plant more land.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pay for land preparation costs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy feed for her cattle.

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella is a married woman with three children, ages ranging from three to eight years. She describes herself as committed. 

She sells vegetables, eggs and cereal and has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a suitable place and her primary customers are locals. 

Isabella will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more vegetables. Her business goal is to have a large scale business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a successful family. 

This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: buy more vegetables.

loans.name: Syeda Zahoor

texts.en:
Syeda Zahoor is the responsible mother of seven children. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. 

Her husband has been providing transportation by driving a taxi for five years. Her husband is responsible to fulfill the needs of the entire family. Her husband needs to have maintenance work done to his taxi because the current condition of his taxi is not good and requires repairs on a daily basis. Due to insufficient financial means her husband is unable to do the necessary maintenance of his taxi. Therefore, Syeda Zahoor has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

With the help of this loan Syeda Zahoor's husband will be able to afford the maintenance costs easily, and therefore provide better transportation to earn a profitable income. 

Syeda Zahoor  also plans to start putting aside money for savings from the profit amount of her husband's income, in order to meet her family's needs in the future.

Syeda Zahoor is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to pay for her husband's taxi repairs

loans.name: Lilit

texts.en:
Lilit is a teacher working at a local school in Armavir town. She lives with her husband and two children. Besides her work in the school, Lilit provides individual trainings after classes. To be able to receive children in her house and organize individual after-class trainings, Lilit has applied for this loan. She needs to purchase a computer, tables and chairs. She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products.

Lilit is a devoted and hardworking teacher and hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for a computer, tables and chairs to provide individual trainings in the home.

loans.name: Mihran

texts.en:
Mihran rents two coffee vending machines in the center of Kapan town, and is responsible for keeping them in operational condition. 

He isn't married and lives with his parents. Mihran is the main worker in the family. 

Needing to enlarge the business he started last year, Mihran wants to purchase his own coffee vending machine. 

That's the reason he has applied for this loan. Mihran has been approved for a loan involving Kiva lenders and SEF international. Its start-up loan program helps informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. 

The loan will be a big support for Mihran, and he hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for a coffee vending machine.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a married man. He has 3 children. He describes himself as honest. 

Stephen operates a butcher shop. He has been involved in this business for 7 years. His business is located in a competitive area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. 

He will use the 90,000 KES loan to buy inventory of meat. His business goal is to be a supplier within 5 years. 

He hopes that in the future, he will have a quality life. 

This is his fourth  loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more meat

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a Kiva borrower. He describes himself as competent. 

He operates a farm where he grows maize and also keeps cows. He has been involved in this business for 2 years. His business is located in a productive area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be bad weather. 

He will use the 30,000 KES loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. 

He hopes that in the future, he will have a stable income. 

This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to plant more land.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Ndiege

texts.en:
Ndiege is a married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself as God fearing. 

He operates a retail business where he sells electronics. He has been involved in this business for 2 years. His business is located in a good area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be changes in prices. 

He will use the 30,000 KES loan to buy more inventory of electronics.  This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

His business goal is to expand his business within 5 years. 

He hopes that in the future he will be leader in the market.

loans.use: to buy more inventory of electronics

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, all of which go to school. She takes care of one additional family member. 

Rose operates a beauty salon in a shop that she rents. She has been in this business for the last 7 years. She works seven days a week. 

She has requested a loan from MCDT – SACCO to buy boxes of hair relaxers, treatments, shampoo, and braids. Her major challenge includes power shortages. 

Her goal is to educate her children up to university level. 

She lives in her own house with access to electricity, but does not have access to piped water. 

Her major monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy boxes of hair relaxers, treatments, shampoo, braids, etc

loans.name: Benta's Group

texts.en:
Benta is a 51-year-old proud mother of six children. She is a group leader, often described as a very friendly person, and is representing her group of 15 farmers from the Matete district. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2013, Benta has noticed that she has been able to consistently feed her family.

Benta described her harvest as good last year but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. She is very excited to be purchasing two solar lights in addition to fertilizer and maize because she will now be able to have light during the dark hours for her children to study. With the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to send her children to school.

With this loan, Benta’s Group will be able to plant a total of 6.75 acres of land and purchase a total of 12 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase two solar lights and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Ngala's Group

texts.en:
Ngala is 46 years old and has 6 children. He is a group leader and is representing his group formed by 14 farmers in Matete District, Kenya. 

Ngala has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2011. This decision was largely a result of his desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods.  Although he described his last harvest as good, he believes he could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Ngala also decided to purchase a solar light as part of his loan, which he is very excited about, as it will allow him to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money.

Obtaining this loan means that Ngala's Group will be able to receive a total of 7 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 7.25 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en:
Joyce is a 53-year-old proud mother of 7 children. She is a group leader, often described as a very hardworking individual, and is representing her group of 13 farmers in Matete District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2014, Joyce has noticed that she has had more profits from each harvest.

Joyce described her harvest as excellent last year, but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. She is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because she will now be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore, save more money. With the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to save more money for the future.

With this loan, Joyce’s Group will be able to plant a total of 8.5 acres of land and purchase a total of 8 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane is a 34-year-old proud mother of 7 children. She is a group leader, often described as a very friendly person, and is representing her group of 14 farmers in Matete District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2013, Jane has noticed that she has gained a lot of respect in her community.

Jane described her harvest as excellent last year, but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. She is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because she will now be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. With the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to send her children to school.

With this loan, Jane’s Group will be able to plant a total of 7 acres of land and purchase a total of 10 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation

loans.name: Chemutai

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Chemutai, twenty three years old, married and blessed with one child. She joined Hand in hand Eastern Africa in 2014.

Chemutai does maize, potato and banana farming on her small farm. She is grateful for HiH EA enterprise training that has enabled her to manage the enterprise well. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizer that will help increase yields, thus getting a better income to enable her to support basic family needs such as education, medical care and clothing.

She is happy with Kiva and its lenders for their intervention. She promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer that will increase crop yield.

loans.name: Kilombero Group

texts.en:
Nusfati is a businesswoman who has been running a business of telephone money transfer known as M-Pesa and Tigo Pesa. Soft-drink selling is her second business, where she buys and sells sodas and juices. She has been in these businesses for two years now, working from 8am to 10pm daily. With this working time range, Nusfati is able to make a good profit each month. She is single and in her late 20's. 

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is her third credit request to be apportioned among Kilombero, a two-member group. The group members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. She used the previous loans, since repaid back successfully, to buy soft drinks for her business and to recharge her telephone money transfer accounts to grow capital. Nusfati managed to generate some extra income, which she used to reinvest in her business and to cover her life expenses. She dreams to one day be able to improve her services and live a better life.

With this credit request, Nusfati will invest a portion of it to recharge her M-Pesa and Tigo Pesa accounts to service more people.

loans.use: to recharge her M-Pesa and Tigo Pesa accounts to service more people

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy another motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow to enable her to meet the demands of customers

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 55 years old and married.  He is blessed with 8 children.  He has operated a farming business for 15 years and it has been profitable. 

Thomas requested a loan to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers, seedlings, and farm machinery.  With the anticipated profit, he will be able to repay his loan and pay his laborers.

His hopes and dreams for the future are to produce farm products in large quantities for sale.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs like fertilizers, seedlings, and farm machinery.

loans.name: Linet's Group

texts.en:
"Pictured above is Linet, who, as a group leader, is representing her group formed by 11 farmers in Matete District, Kenya. She is married and is a mother to 4 children.  She is known by her community as a very friendly person.

Initially, Linet joined One Acre Fund in 2011 because she wanted to earn enough to send her children to school. Since she joined the program she says that her life has improved, especially because she has been able to consistently feed her family. With the profits from the upcoming harvesting season, Linet plans to send her children to school.

Between the 11 farmers in Linet's Group, a total of 8.25 acres of land will be planted using the maize seeds and fertilizer received with the loan. Additionally, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light so with this loan, the group will also receive a total of 3 solar lights."

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvests of maize

loans.name: Kpanmanga- Makayili Group

texts.en:
Alice is a 47-year-old hardworking woman from Makayili in the Northern region of Ghana. Amina is married and has two children. She is the individual pictured with her hand raised among members sitting.

Alice is a member of a parboiled rice processing group that has been in business for the last seven years. The name of the group is ‘Kpanmanga- Makayili’. She earns a good profit from the business simply because the group has been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to process high quality parboiled rice for the Ghanaian local markets.

Alice and ‘Kpanmanga- Makayili’ group have asked for a loan of GHS 18,300. Her share of the loan is GHS 500, which she would use to buy paddy rice from rice farmers for processing. Alice aspires to produce more processed parboiled rice and supply it to the Ghana School Feeding Programme caterers and earn more income so as to repay this loan and support her family with food and educational expenses.
Alice thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy paddy rice from rice farmers for processing.

loans.name: Joseph's Group

texts.en:
Joseph is 43 years old and has six children. He has been a farmer for 10 years and is always said to be a very hardworking individual. Even though Joseph is the only one featured in the above picture, he is actually representing his group formed by 14 farmers in Matete District, Kenya.

Joseph started working alongside One Acre Fund a few years ago, in 2010, and decided to do so because he wanted to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. Since then, he has seen his life improve; especially in the sense that he has had more profits from each harvest ever since. This year he decided to represent his group because he wanted to gain leadership skills.

Joseph’s Group will receive farming inputs to plant a total of 9.25 acres of land. Additionally, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light, so with this loan the group will also receive a total of four solar lights.

loans.use: to buy cost efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvest season.

loans.name: Everlyne's Group

texts.en:
Everlyne, in the photo, is a group leader and is representing her group formed by ten farmers from the Matete district, Kenya. She joined One Acre Fund for the first time in 2011 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to spread the story of One Acre Fund farmers. She is married and has three children.

With this loan, Everlyne will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season but also two solar lights. Receiving two solar lights as part of her loan means that now she will be able to have an overall improved quality of life. Everlyne plans to use the profits she gains this year to send her children to school.

In total, Everlyne’s Group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of 6.5 acres of land. They will also receive a total of seven solar lights.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season as well as two solar lights.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pesticides to spray on his watermelon garden.

loans.name: Shamshad

texts.en:
Shamshad is a 24 year old single lady. The income generated by her father is insufficient to cover all household expenses, so she started a business selling milk. She has been doing this for many years and has become well-known for providing good quality milk in her locality. 

With the support of Kashf Foundation, she has gradually improved her business.  Currently she has requested for a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase another buffalo to increase sales and earn profits to provide her family with the basic necessities of life.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo to increase her sales

loans.name: Sayniso

texts.ru: Сайнисо 39 летняя жительница района Хурусон. Она замужем и мать четверых детей. Сайнисо в районе живет вместе мужем, тестю и детьми. Сайнисо на районе занимается сельскохозяйственной деятельности. Она у себя во дворе выращивает молодых телят. Сайнисо покупает молодых телят и откармливает их в течение нескольких месяцев, прежде чем принимать их на рынок перепродажи. Этой деятельности она занимается уже 5 лет. Сайнисо обратилась за кредитом, чтобы купить несколько молодых телят и расширить деятельность. Она заранее выражает свою благодарность.
texts.en:
Sayniso is a 39-year-old resident of the Khuroson region. She is married and has four children. She lives in the region with her husband, her father-in-law and her children. She works in agriculture, raising young calves in her yard. She buys young calves and fattens them over several months before taking them to the market to resell. She has been working in this business for five years.

Sayniso is looking for a loan to buy a few young calves to expand her business. She expresses her thanks in advance.

loans.use: to buy a few young calves and expand her business

loans.name: Shadrack

texts.en: Shadrack is a married man. He has one child. He describes himself to be honest. He operates a retail business where he sells timber. He has been involved in this business for 15 years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital. He will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy more stock of timber. He will use the anticipated profits to meet family needs.

loans.use: to buy more stock of timber.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 43 years old and married with four children. All of them are in school.

Lucia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase additional stock of groceries to sell.

Lucia has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from rice retailing.

Lucia aspires to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of groceries to sell.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a seasoned 55-year-old farmer from Kanjogu Village in the Central region of Kenya.  David is able to provide for his family through dairy and crop farming.  He has been farming for as long as he can remember. 

David is seeking a loan of 50,000 KES to replace his old farming tools.  Worn out tools are bad for business as they are inefficient and provide poor quality work output.  With your loan, David will be able to purchase new and modern tools, that are efficient, and easier and comfortable to use.  These new implements will enable him to work faster and without as much effort as the old tools would require.  He believes the quality of crops would be great too due to proper seedbed preparation.

Your investment will make it possible for David to keep producing quality produce for his customers and in turn earn his family a decent living.

loans.use: to buy farm implements, such as modern tools.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica, 27, comes from Biego village in the Nyamira region of Kenya. This year, Veronica celebrates her eighth year in marriage with Thomas, the father of her two children (sadly, one died).

To support Thomas in providing for their family, Veronica started farming in the year 2005. Today, her two-acre farm holds two dairy cows, ten head of poultry, and a field of maize/corn.

Veronica is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase cereal grains. These grains will act as seeds during the planting season, food for Veronica's family, and a commodity for trade. Enterprising farmers usually aggregate cereal produce from local farmers and sell it in lucrative urban markets that offer better prices. This trade helps farmers like Veronica to roll back cereal profits into the business and use the money to settle part of the high cost of inputs.

loans.use: to buy cereal grains.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy coffee for selling.

loans.name: Hanna's Group

texts.en:
Akua is a 56-year-old woman from Makayili in the northern region of Ghana. Akua is married and has two children. Akua is the individual pictured with the hand raised among members standing.

Akua is a member of a shea nuts processing group that has been in business for the last 10 years. The name of the group is ‘Titritob - Makayili’. Akua earns a good profit from the business as the group has been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to improve their shea nuts processing business such that they can always produce premium quality for the local markets and non-local markets.

Akua and ‘Titritob - Makayili’ have asked for a loan of GHS 17,550. Akua’s share of the loan is GHS 1,400, which she would use to pick and process shea nuts to make crude butter. She aspires to earn more income as well as to repay this loan and support her family's health and children's educational needs.

Akua thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To pick and process shea nuts to make crude butter.

loans.name: Fauzia

texts.en:
Fauzia is a married mother of two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenges of seasonality and transportation in her place of operations.

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 40,000 she wants to purchase new clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase new clothes for resale

loans.name: Ngiini Grace S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The person with her hand raised in the photo is Janefer. She is an active member of Ngiini Grace S.H.G Group. She is 41 years old, married and the mother of three children. She joined hand in hand eastern Africa (HiH EA) in April 2014 to equip herself with entrepreneurial skills.

Janefer sells secondhand clothes and shoes at the nearby market and is borrowing to buy more secondhand clothes and shoes, hence increasing stock and realizing more profits.

She is grateful to Kiva and her lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy secondhand clothes and shoes, hence increasing stock and realizing more profits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is a married woman and has one child. She describes herself to be supportive. She operates a restaurant and she has been involved in this business for two years. Mercy's business is located in a good area and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more stocks of ingredients for preparing food. Her business goal is to increase profits within five years. This is Mercy's second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of ingredients for preparing food.

loans.name: Siasa

texts.en:
Siasa is a married mother of one child, who does not attend school. Siasa lives at her own house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past eight months, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of a high cost for transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future.

With the loan that Siasa is requesting of 20,000 KES she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 33-year-old hardworking married man with a baby of 9 months. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. He is a farmer, mainly growing coffee and sugar cane. He also earns more income from a salary.

He hopes to complete his family’s house, grow his coffee plantation into a modern farm, and buy a coffee processing machine so as to add value to his products and sell at a price that will make him smile. His vision is hindered by the dry season, which destroys the coffee seeds and causes capital inadequacy.

He is requesting a loan to finish the construction of his house.

loans.use: to finish the construction of his house.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Imagine investing in a venture and reaping nothing at the end of the day. This is the sad story of Peter, a youthful 29 wise farmer whose neighbors and fellow farmers respect as a mentor. He farms a small plot of land in the green, lush hills near Nandihills, in the northern Rift Valley region of Kenya where he grows maize and keeps dairy animals. Peter's farming experience dates back to 2000. 

Like many other farmers in the region, Tea is a cash crop which he has been planting for as long as he can remember. With time, the fertility of his land has started to dwindle and whenever he plants tea the yields go down with each growing season. Peter has also been affected with weeds. 

Today, Peter requests a loan from Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva lenders to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and good quality seeds. Through this loan Peter is going to increase his crop production and improve his income.

This loan will permanently change Peter's living standards and there is no doubt that he will find rewarding employment in farming. Support the entrepreneurial dreams of a Kenyan with a loan today!

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pasticide, and good quality seeds

loans.name: Cristo Cesar

texts.es:
Cristo es un hombre de 35 años de edad, se dedica al comercio de bebidas, está es su forma de ganarse la vida, gracias a esta profesión genera el sustento para el mantenimiento de su familia que la conforman su pareja y 3 hijas de 2, 4 y 6, ellas son todo para Cristo, cada día trata de ser mejor empresario, ganar dinero para poder darles una alimentación y nutrición adecuada, estudio, muñecas para que se diviertan y siempre sonrían.

Cristo tiene el negocio en su casa, no tiene una empresa montada, aprovecha su nevera y allí deposita su mercancía, es un comerciante minorista, sus clientes son personas de barrio, vecinos, cualquier sediento que busque una bebida refrescante.

Cristo tiene un deseo en su mente. Para él sería ideal poder tener un expendio de distribución mayorista de bebidas y quiere trabajar duro para conseguirlo, mientras tiene que procurar por seguir sosteniendo su hogar y asegurar el estudio de sus hijas.

Cristo solicita un préstamo para la compra de bebidas refrescantes y cervezas, busca abastecer su negocio.
texts.en:
Cristo is 35 years old, and works in the drinks business. This is his way of earning a living, and thanks to this profession he generates the livelihood to maintain his family which is made up of his wife and three daughters ages 2, 4, and 6. They mean everything to Cristo. He tries every day to be a better businessman and earn money to give them adequate food and nutrition, schooling, and dolls, so that they have fun and always smile.

Cristo has a business in his house. He doesn't have an established company, and takes advantage of his own refrigerator where he keeps his inventory. He is a small retailer and his customers are people from the area, neighbors, and any thirsty person that is looking for a refreshing drink.

Cristo has a goal in mind. For him it would be ideal to have an outlet for the wholesale distribution of drinks, and he wants to work hard to achieve it. Meanwhile he has to strive to continue sustaining his household and assure the education of his daughters. He is requesting a loan to buy refreshing beverages and beers; he wants to supply his business.

loans.use: to supply his refrigerators with refreshing beverages and beers.

loans.name: Dolly Del Carmen

texts.es:
Ella es Dolly, una mujer de carácter y buena voluntad, con deseos de progresar y salir adelante con su familia.

Ella decidió por iniciar con un negocio de cafetería desde hace aproximadamente 1 año en un pequeño local con muchas ganas y empuje. 

Este oficio lo aprendió de manera empírica, con la necesidad y el gusto por las ventas, esto le permitió obtener gran experiencia.

Hoy en día desea darle un pequeño impulso a su negocio con la ayuda de los prestadores de Kiva y la Corporación Interactuar, por esta razón requiere un préstamo para comprar insumos para sus preparaciones y una plancha para carne.

Con este crédito podrá sostener su negocio y hacerlo crecer cada día más.

Es una mujer que asume retos y los enfrenta con valentía.
texts.en:
This is Dolly, a woman of character and will who wants to progress and move forward with her family. 
She decided to start her own cafeteria business about a year ago and opened it in a small premises. She is very eager and enthusiastic. 
She learned this work empirically, through necessity and because she has a taste for sales, and through this she gained good experience. 
Today she wants to give her business a little boost with the help of the Kiva lenders and the Corporación Interactuar. So, she is requesting a loan to buy supplies to prepare meals and to buy a meat grill.
She will be able to sustain her business with this loan and grow it every day.
She is a woman who takes on challenges and faces them bravely.

loans.use: to buy supplies to prepare meals and to buy a meat grill.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema, a married woman, owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. Rehema operates a charcoal business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces  stiff competition from other firewood operators in her business.
 
With this Kshs 40,000 loan, Rehama will purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Manzoora

texts.en:
Manzoora is a 52-year-old married woman and a mother of two children. In order to support her husband in taking care of the family, she began the business of milk selling. She is known in her town for providing good-quality milk.

She owns buffaloes for milking. She is happily supporting her family with the income generated. She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase another buffalo to inflate her sales for generating more income to cover her daily expenses.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo to inflate her sales for generating more income to cover her daily expenses.

loans.name: Rosalba Del Rocio

texts.es:
Rosalba es una mujer de 61 años de edad, se dedico inicialmente al negocio de las confecciones en el cual duro tres años como operaria, después de pasar este periodo de tiempo inicio con un taller propio.

Vive con sola y es viuda. Hace 5 años es una mujer independiente que gracias a los micro créditos tiene la posibilidad de ser su propia jefe pues su pecera es reconocida por su buen servicio al cliente; solicita el crédito para la compra de 2 maquinas de confección, pues desea aumentar su capacidad de producción y generar empleo.
