Ella cada vez que recibe un crédito lo invierte en productos lo cual le ha servido para aumentar su clientela, ella también vende productos Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos,  perfumería y accesorios de damas), tiene en su tienda unas vitrinas en las cuales  vende sus productos de bazar, su hija le ayuda y más cuando su marido se dedica a la agricultura, lleva más de 20 años con su tienda. 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir más su tienda y comprar víveres, frutas, legumbres  y todo lo que ellos venden en su local. Lleva dos ciclos en el Grupo de Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan con los créditos. Sus sueños seguir mejorando su negocio.
texts.en:
The town of La Mocora, in the parish of the city of Portoviejo, a place known for its hard working people working in agriculture and livestock, is where the members of the Grupo de Crédito meet twice a month.

Rosa lives here. She is 61 years old. She is married and through this relationship she has 5 adult children. The youngest still lives with them. Her husband is a farmer.

Rosa and her husband have a grocery store in their home. There they sell all kinds of groceries such as rice, sugar, oil, detergents, vegetables, meat, bazaar items, water in large containers, soda, and candy. Each time she receives a loan she invests in products which have served to increase her clientele. She also sells Yanbal (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume, and accessories for women). In her store she has some showcases from which she sells her bazaar products. Her daughter helps her, especially when her husband is farming. She has had her store for more than 20 years.

She is going to use this loan to supply her store by buying groceries, fruit, vegetables and everything that they sell in the store. She has been with the Grupo de Crédito for two cycles and she likes it because of the help they offer the borrowers. She dreams of continuing to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy food, fruits, vegetables, etc. to stock her grocery store

loans.name: Amaranta Alegria

texts.es:
En la localidad La Mocora de la parroquia Colon de la ciudad de Portoviejo lugar conocido por su gente trabajadora y dedicada a la agricultura y la ganadería cada quince días se reúnen los socios del Grupo De Crédito La Mocora
En este lugar vive la señora Amaranta, tiene 59 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tuvo 4 hijos pero un falleció, los  tres que aun tiene son mayores de edad, uno de ellos aun vive con ella. El marido es comerciante. 
Doña Amaranta es una muy buena esposa que le gusta ayudarle a su marido a solventar los gastos del hogar, con la ayuda del crédito anterior emprendió un pequeño negocio de venta de ropa de todo tipo, a ella siempre le ha gustado el comercio y así por temporadas vende sus prendas con lo cual se gana algo. Parte del crédito ella se lo da a  su marido para que él lo utilice en sus actividades, el vende frutas, queso, maní molido y varios productos que lleva a entregara a Guayaquil donde tiene muy buena clientela.  Gracias a los créditos su vida ha mejorado razón por lo cual está muy agradecida con la institución y con Kiva que hacen esto posible.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa de todo tipo, frutas, queso y maní. Esta desde el inicio  en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que recibe con los créditos. Sus sueños son seguir mejorando su vida.
texts.en: In the community of La Mocora—located in the Colon parish of the city of Portoviejo and known for hard-working residents who make a living from agriculture and raising livestock—the members of the La Moncora credit group meet every fifteen days. This is the home of Ms. Amaranta, who is 59 years old. She lives with her life partner, with whom she has four children, one of which passed away and three which are adults. Of these three, one still lives with her. Her husband works as a merchant. Ms. Amaranta is a good wife who likes to help her husband with household expenses. With the help of a previous loan, she was able to establish a small business selling clothing of all kinds. She has always liked trading and sells her clothing in seasons to earn something extra. She gives some of her earnings to her husband to use in his business—he sells fruits, cheese, ground peanuts, and several products that he takes to Guayaquil where he has very good clients. Thanks to the loans, her life has improved and she is very grateful to the organization and Kiva, who make it possible. She is requesting this loan to purchase clothing of all kinds, fruit, cheese, and peanuts. Ms. Amaranta has been in the credit group since its foundation and likes the help she receives through the loans. Her dream is to continue to improve her life.

loans.use: to purchase clothing, fruit, cheese, and peanuts.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan tiene 35 años de edad, vive junto a su esposa e hijos en una zona rural del distrito de Pucará, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, se encuentra ubicada en la Provincia de Jaén que pertenece a la Región Cajamarca, sierra norte del Perú.

El se dedica al cultivo de café, desde hace 10 años por lo que cuenta con experiencia en este negocio y con buenas referencias personales y laborales en la zona. El préstamo lo utilizará para la compra de abonos y fertilizantes para brindar mantenimiento a su cultivo de café, con esto el espera ofrecer un café de mejor calidad a sus clientes lo que le permitirá incrementar su nivel de ingresos y por ende va a mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Juan is 35 years old and lives together with his wife and children in a rural area in the Pucará district, whose population makes a living from agriculture, trade and animal husbandry. It is located in the Jaén province, Cajamarca region, in the northern mountains of Peru.

He has been making a living from coffee farming for 10 years, so he has experience in this business and good personal and work references in the area. He will use the loan to buy manure and fertilisers to maintain his coffee plants. With this, he hopes to sell better quality coffee to his customers. This will allow him to increase his income level and he will therefore improve the quality of life of himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy manure and fertilisers to maintain his coffee plants

loans.name: Elmelyn

texts.en:
Elmelyn was able to access a 50,000 PHP loan through Kiva, which she used to purchase grocery items and other stuff she needed in her variety store. It also helped her to pay her personal, household, and business expenses. 

Elmelyn would like to apply for another loan, this time in the amount of 45,000 PHP. She needs the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from her business will help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Elmelyn hopes to have her own supermarket someday and a car as well, if God will allow. She dreams of seeing her children finish their studies also of a better life in the future. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Bendalie

texts.en:
Bendalie is 42 years old and married with seven children, three of whom are in school. Bendalie works very hard to provide for them.

Bendalie has run a general store in the Philippines for three years, and she has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks of household goods to sell.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of household goods to sell

loans.name: Kanaani Mukalala S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand is Jenny, who is married with two children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from its training, especially on enterprise development and financial management.

Jenny is practicing livestock and she keeps chicken and dairy cows. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy dairy feeds and chicken feeds to increase her production of eggs and milk.

She is grateful to Kiva and her lenders.

loans.use: To buy dairy feeds and chicken feeds to increase production of eggs and milk.

loans.name: Piquiñani Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “PIQUIÑANI” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Patacamaya, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Nieves es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: servicio de albañil, venta de leche, venta de papa y quinua, servicio de transporte.
	
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Nieves es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una promoción masiva de la institución que realizaron en su zona. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de leche; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió al observa a una amiga, quien tenía el mismo negocio, con el pasar del tiempo y con sus ahorros decide emprender un negocio independiente.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de ganado) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de su comunidad y posteriormente, a la crianza, comercializará este producto a las empresas embotelladoras. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es soltera y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The PIQUIÑANI community association will start their first lending cycle in Pro Mujer as part of the Patacamaya Focal Centre. It is composed of eight members and is headed by an executive board in which Nieves is the president. The businesses of the members of the community association are varied and include: bricklaying, sale of milk, sale of potatoes and quinoa, and transportation services.

The loan that they are requesting will benefit small business owners including Nieves. She indicates that it is the first time that she is [requesting a loan] as a member of Pro Mujer, entering it after a massive promotional campaign was done in her area. She currently has a business selling milk. She tells that she started this business by observing a friend who had the same type of business. With time and her savings she decides to start an independent business.

The loan that she is requesting will be used to increase her capital (purchase of cattle), which she will buy from the wholesalers in her community, and after raising them, she will sell this product [milk] to the bottling companies. This way of working allows her to generate income to economically support her family, as she is single and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she replies that she likes the courses offered by the institution.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Loay

texts.en:
Loay is a 31-year-old married man from a village near the city of Jenin. He is the father of four sons and one daughter. He collects used metal stuff, recycles it, and then sells it as a raw iron bars.

Loay would like to improve his business. so he has requested a loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new machine for pressing the raw iron. This loan will allow him to press the bars himself instead of paying for this service. 

Loay appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new machine for pressing raw iron.

loans.name: Victorine

texts.en:
Victorine is a married woman with 4 children. She describes herself as focused and disciplined. 

Victorine operates a salon where she offers beauty services. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge as inflation. Victorine will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy more stocks of beauty products. Her business goal is to open another branch within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, she will have good living conditions. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stocks of beauty products

loans.name: Kateve Muuo W.g Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Mbindu. She is a member of Kateve Muuo Women Group and she joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 to benefit from enterprise development training. She is 56 years old, married, and blessed with six children.

Mbindu practices both crop and dairy farming. She is borrowing to buy seedlings for her tree nurseries, which she is planning to fully commercialize in order to supplement her income.
 
She is grateful to Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: To buy seedlings for her tree nurseries

loans.name: Holbibi

texts.en: Holbibi is a hardworking woman. She was born into a family of workers in 1964. She lives in the southern part of Tajikistan with her big family. She is married and has four children. Holbibi has many years of experience trading in the general store. She sells washing powders, soaps, cleaning powders, and other items. She has permanent clients who shop at her store every day. She works hard in order to feed their family. She appealed to IMON and KIVA lenders for a loan to buy goods and renew her inventory. She hopes to sell more goods and feed her family. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy goods and renew her inventory

loans.name: Rositas De Tiquina Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ROSITAS DE TIQUINA” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Martha es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de dulces, venta de polleras, tienda de barrio, venta de comida, venta de verduras, venta de pescado.
	
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Martha es integrante, ella indica que hace cinco años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una promoción masiva de la institución que realizaron en su zona. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de pescado; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió al apoyar a su familia en el negocio familiar, con el pasar del tiempo y con unos ahorros decide emprender un negocio independiente.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de refrigerador) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente, lo implementará para la conserva de sus productos. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tiene cuatro hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The Rositas De Tiquina communal bank will begin its first cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Copacabana regional center.  It is comprised of eight members and led by a board of directors.  Martha is the president.  The businesses of the members of the communal bank are varied and include selling sweets, selling traditional skirts, a neighborhood store, selling food, selling vegetables, and selling fish.

The loan that they will take out will benefit small businesswomen where Martha is a member.  She says that she has been a member of Pro Mujer for five years.  She joined by invitation from a massive promotion that the institution conducted in her area.  

She currently has a business of selling fish.  She says that she learned this business to support her family in the family business.  As time passed she decided to use her savings to undertake an independent business.

The loan that she will now take out is to increase capital (to buy a refrigerator) that she will get from the wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz.  She will then use it to preserve her products.  This way of working allows her to generate resources to help the family financially.  She is married and has four children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responded that she likes the training that the institution offers.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Kantutitas Del Sol Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “KANTUTITAS DEL SOL” iniciará el segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Panamericana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Julia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de salchipapa, venta de colchones, venta de pescado, venta de polleras, venta de faldas, venta de papa.
	
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Julia es integrante, ella indica que hace un año que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una promoción masiva de la institución que realizaron en su zona. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de costura de faldas; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió de su madre, quien tenía el mismo negocio, sin embargo ella estudio la especialización de pollerería para mejoramiento de la calidad de productos, es por esta razón que trabaja con este negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de telas por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente, lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella vive en concubinato y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones y el área de salud que ofrece la institución.

En la imagen no esta presente una cliente, la misma se marcho por razones personales.
texts.en:
The Kantutitas Del Sol communal bank will begin its second cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Panamericana regional center.  It is comprised of eight members and led by a board of directors.  Julia is the president.  The businesses of the members of the communal bank are varied and include selling ‘salchipapas’ [sausages and fried potatoes], selling fish, selling traditional skirts, selling skirts, and selling potatoes.

The loan that they will take out will benefit small businesswomen where Julia is a member.  She says that she has been a member of Pro Mujer for one year.  She joined by invitation from a massive promotion that the institution conducted in her area.  She currently has a business of making skirts.  She says that she learned this business from her mother, who had the same business.  Nevertheless, she studied the specialization of making traditional skirts in order to improve the quality of her products.  That is the reason that she works with this business.

The loan that she will now take out is to increase capital (to buy fabric wholesale).  She will get the fabric from the wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz.  She will later sell at her sales space.  This way of working allows her to generate resources to help her family financially.  She is in a common-law marriage and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responded that she likes the training and the health services that the institution offers.

One client [of the institution] is not in the picture because she left for personal reasons.

loans.use: to buy fabric wholesale.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 27-year-old married man from Khanyounis city. He is a father for one daughter. Two years ago, Mohammad opened a mobile store where he sells and repairs mobile phones. He would like to improve his business and expand it.

Mohammad took a USD Murabaha loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new laptop for his business. By taking this loan, Mohammad will be able to transfer mobile units to the clients. This will increase his income and improve his store. 

Mohammad appears in the photo with his new laptop.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his mobile store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase trees and timber for charcoal

loans.name: Sharon's Group

texts.en:
Sharon's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Sharon is 18 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Sharon has been working hard to manage her charcoal business. 

To help expand her business, Sharon has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal, and it should help her to generate greater profits by adding sacks of charcoal to her inventory. Sharon hopes that, in the future, she will be able to return to school. 

Sharon is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Kabahango Kisomoro Tweyimukye Group

texts.en: Joseph is a member of Kabahango Kisomoro Tweyimukye, in which the members guarantee each other's loans. He has 12 children and lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is involved in farming and running a retail shop that sells items like sugar, salt, matches, cooking oil, soap and biscuits. He is faced with challenges that hinder the progress of his business, like low capital and defaulters. However, he has a vision of increasing his family income. Joseph has asked for a loan to add to his stock of general merchandise to sell in his retail shop.

loans.use: to add to his stock of general merchandise like sugar, salt, matches, cooking oil, soap and biscuits to sell in his retail shop.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is 23 years old, married and supports a family of four members. He has been operating in brick making for the last six years and earns KES 7,000 per month.

Amos has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to buy a grinder for brick making. 

He plans to use the anticipated profits to educate his children. His future hopes and dreams are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a grinder for brick making.

loans.name: Peninah

texts.en:
The lady appearing in the photo is Peninah, who is 25 years old, married and blessed with two children. She joined Hand in Hand eastern Africa (HIH EA) in June 2014.

Peninah runs a tree nursery where she sells tree seedlings to earn a living. She is grateful to HiH EA for developing an entrepreneurship spirit in her through training and mentorship programs. 

She is borrowing a Kiva loan to purchase tree seeds for propagation. She believes with a variety of trees for sale, she will attract more customers to her nursery, and hence, more income to enable her to support her young family's needs, such as food and education for her children.

Peninah is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for their support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to purchase tree seeds that will her boost tree nursery business.

loans.name: Kyeni Kya Kamuthini Women Group

texts.en:
Dorcas is the woman raising her hand in the photo. She is the mother of three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 to benefit from the savings mobilization and enterprise development trainings.

To supplement her income, Dorcas is currently involved in baking and selling buns to a nearby primary school in her neighborhood. She is borrowing from Kiva in order to buy more ingredients such as wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oils for baking buns, which will enable her satisfy the rising demand for her buns in her neighborhood.

She is grateful to Kiva and her lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to satisfy the rising demand for her buns in her neighborhood.
